history: The riverside city of Stonebridge grew around a single ancient bridge of unknown make. For centuries it served as a toll stop between northern farms and southern ports. After a flood ruined nearby rivals, Stonebridge’s guilds seized control of trade and declared the Bridge Charter—simple laws posted on the bridge itself. The city is peaceable but proud; every dispute is judged at the bridge steps, and every caravan leaves a tithe stone.

locations.name: Stonebridge
locations.summary: A bustling medieval market-city clustered around an indestructible stone span over the Greywash River.

sublocations.name: Market Square
sublocations.summary: Stalls of cloth, grain, and ironwork; town criers read the Bridge Charter at noon.

sublocations.name: The River Lantern
sublocations.summary: Low-beamed tavern near the bridge abutment; warm stew, louder rumors.

sublocations.name: The Old Bridge
sublocations.summary: Seamless stone arch bearing carved tally-marks of paid tithes.

sublocations.name: Lower Docks
sublocations.summary: Barges and ferries crowd timber piers; fishmongers shout the tide’s price.

sublocations.name: Bridgeward Keep
sublocations.summary: Stout tower overseeing tolls and city watches; bells signal river traffic.

sublocations.name: Temple of the Three Hours
sublocations.summary: Clerics mark dawn, noon, and dusk with chimes; pilgrims leave river stones.

sublocations.name: Guildhall Row
sublocations.summary: Weavers, chandlers, and carters share a long timber hall where deals are sealed with wax.

sublocations.name: East Gate
sublocations.summary: Caravans queue beneath iron-toothed portcullis; inspectors check wheel-marks.

sublocations.name: The Warren
sublocations.summary: Tight alleys and leaning tenements; lanterns strung on laundry lines.
